awd_titl_txt: Natural Abundance Si-29 and O-17 NMR Methods for Measuring Silicate Glass Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry is supporting Professor Philip Grandinetti at Ohio State University to develop high-throughput methods for characterizing the atomic level structure of glasses using nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy. Glasses have been used by mankind for millennia.  The first historical record of man-made glasses appears as far back as 4500 years ago and the use of glass in windows began over 2000 years ago. Today the technological and economical impact of glassy materials is both immense and diverse.  Despite its technological success, glass scientists and engineers still often resort to Edisonian approaches in attempts to understand the chemical compositions of glasses with desired properties.  This is because the physical and chemical processes responsible for the properties of glasses and for glass transition are incompletely understood.  Professor Grandinetti and his coworkers aim to achieve significantly higher throughput NMR measurements on such samples by optimally integrating two NMR sensitivity enhancement strategies, echo train acquisition and paramagnetic relaxation enhancement. Such high throughput NMR measurements in silicate glasses would considerably expand the range of chemical compositions that could be studied and eliminate the burden and cost of preparing isotopically enriched samples. This would have benefits for scientists studying the physics, chemistry, and materials science properties of glasses. The project will also provides interdisciplinary training opportunities to undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate students. The PI's ongoing partnership with scientists at the CEMHTI-CNRS lab in Orleans, France, will provide students the opportunity to collaborate across national boundaries. A partnership between Professor Grandinetti and Berea College will provide undergraduate students with summer research opportunities.

In this multi-tiered project, the Grandinetti group will bring natural abundance Si-29 and O-17 2D NMR measurements of oxide glasses into the realm of routine measurements. In an effort to lay the groundwork for this project, the group will develop a next generation dynamic-angle spinning (DAS) probe in partnership with Revolution NMR, LLC. The group will then employ the DAS probe in a suite of complementary 2D NMR measurements to explore a series of thirty binary glass compositions of fundamental interest. In these studies, the Grandinetti lab will quantify the distributions of Si-O distances, Si-O-Si angles, and network-forming anionic species distributions. They will also develop the chemical shift anisotropy of Si-29 and the quadrupolar coupling of O-17 into a qualitative and quantitative probe of network modifier cation clustering, and develop the Si-29 J coupling across a Si-O-Si linkage into a more reliable probe of Si-O-Si angles and network connectivities. Taken together, these studies aim to provide a new level of qualitative and quantitative detail about structural order and disorder in glass.  The structural details of glass to be elucidated through these studies would also benefit scientists seeking to develop thermodynamic models of glasses and melts, and seeking to refine potentials used in molecular dynamics simulations of glasses. Details on modifier cation clustering behavior in glasses will be useful to scientists developing improved structural models of ionic transport, of the mixed alkali effect, and of the microscopic structure of chemically strengthened glass.

por.por_cntn:
While the majority of worldwide glass production focuses on windows and containers, there is a growing demand for improved specialty glasses which have become vital to a large range of technological applications. Despite these expanding needs, a major challenge in tailoring the properties of new glass compositions is that we have few quantitative details about the structure of real glasses--and, of course, all macroscopic properties of a glass are a direct result of its underlying atomic-level structure.  While one of the best probes of microscopic structure in glasses is Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, high throughput NMR measurements that explore a wider range of glass compositions and histories have remained out of reach due to poor sensitivity and the challenges and expense of preparing isotopically labeled samples.  

In this NSF project, Professor Grandinetti and his lab at Ohio State University have made natural abundance silicon-29 and oxygen-17 NMR measurements of silicate glasses routine by optimally integrating two sensitivity enhancement strategies: echo train acquisition, and paramagnetic doping.  Obtaining sensitivity enhancements up to 50-fold enhancements for Si-29, and 1000-fold for O-17 NMR, these advances have enabled them to make more sophisticated and revealing measurements of the silicate glass structure.

The importance of measuring the inter-tetrahedra angle distribution in silicate glasses cannot be overstated. It is the first broken structural constraint, and the variation in these angles is considered to be one of the main sources of disorder in silicate glasses.  In this project, the Grandinetti lab studied the 2D O-17 NMR spectra of silica glasses densified at pressures up to ~13.5 GPa. They found that the onset of structural changes that persist after decompression in vitreous silica is ~8 GPa.  A comparison between the quenched structures up to ~13.5 GPa suggests no significant change in the silicon coordination and ring size distribution.  Instead, they found that the corner-shared tetrahedral network undergoes a decrease in the average Si-O-Si angle and a concomitant increase in the Si-O distance which suggests a compression and possible puckering of the constituent rings.  Contrary to intuition, these structural changes are not elastically recoverable upon decompression as the resulting networks all evolve along the locus of the minima in the Si-O-Si versus Si-O potential energy surface. During this project, the Grandinetti lab also determined the NMR parameter-structure relationship between the inter-nuclear J coupling between Si-29 of connected SiO4 tetrahedra and the inter-tetrahedra angle.  Armed with this relationship they measured the 2D J-resolved natural abundance Si-29 NMR spectrum of silica glass and determined that the inter-tetrahedra angle distribution has a mode at 147 deg., a standard deviation of 10.7 deg., and that the inter-tetrahedra angles are relatively uncorrelated.  An unanticipated outcome from their analysis is a confirmation of the positive correlation between inter-tetrahedra angles and Si-O distance previously determined by their O-17 NMR studies of silica glasses. This outcome suggests that the commonly accepted notion that SiO4 tetrahedra in silica glass are structurally similar to those in crystalline silica polymorphs is incorrect.


The introduction of network-modifying cations into silica, depolymerizes the silicate network by breaking bridging oxygen (BO) linkages and introduces non-bridging oxygen (NBO) linked to one silicon. This depolymerization results in marked changes in physical properties, such as the glass transition temperature, viscosity, mechanical properties, and ionic transport.   While the prediction of these properties relies heavily on structural models for the distribution of modifier cations, obtaining detailed experimental evidence on the full extent of NBO and modifier cation cluster formation, size distributions, and degree of structural order at various length scales has been elusive.  In 2D Si-29 NMR measurements of depolymerized silicate glasses, the Grandinetti lab discovered a linear relationship between Si-29 shielding anisotropy and the Si--NBO bond length.  This bond length, in turn, was found to increase linearly with increasing modifier cation potential and increasing NBO coordination by modifier cations. In NMR investigations of cesium silicate glasses, a systematic decrease in the Si-29 anisotropy with increasing Cs content was observed, and, unexpectedly, two coexisting and structurally distinct tetrahedra environments with different shielding anisotropies, corresponding to longer and shorter Si--NBO bond lengths, were observed.  The concentration onset of the observation of these two sites, associated with different modifier cation cluster sizes, was identified as the percolation threshold of NBO in a sea of BO.

During this grant, the Grandinetti group also developed a commercial version of their in-house designed dynamic-angle spinning NMR probe in partnership with Revolution NMR, LLC.

Taken together, the results of this project offer an unprecedented quantitative details about structural order and disorder in glass and will be valuable in thermodynamic models of glasses and melts and in refining potentials in molecular dynamics simulations of glasses. The new approaches for examining modifier cation clustering behavior in glasses will improve structural models of ionic transport, the mixed alkali effect, and our microscopic understanding of chemically strengthened glass.
